newsitem.title: USA: U.S. stocks down at midday, high techs soft.
newsitem.headline: U.S. stocks down at midday, high techs soft.

text.p: Profit-taking in high-tech issues kept Wall Street stocks lower at midday.

The selling was encouraged by a worse than expected fiscal first quarter loss by Digital Equipment Corp and a better than forecast but far from spectacular Microsoft Corp earnings report, analysts said.
The Dow Industrials were down 23 points, or 0.39 percent, at 6067. The Nasdaq Composite Index, a barometer of high-tech issues, was off 11 points, or 0.88 percent, at 1225.
The long bond was down 5/32 to yield 6.82 percent.
Big Board declines led advancing issues by better than three to two on volume of about 193 million shares.

"The high techs are getting a much needed near-term correction," said Roy Blumberg, chief investment strategist at Josephthal Lyon & Ross. "They have been the leaders of the move higher over the last couple of months. They've had a tremendous run and, as long as the market holds up well, they will have a correction of some five percent."
However, if the market embarks on a significant downward move, the techs would be vulnerable in the ensuing sell-off, he said.
"Not that there is anything wrong with their fundamentals, but when people like stocks they take them too high," Blumberg said. "The techs were taken to levels at which too much is discounted."

Digital Equipment posted a loss of $65.9 million, or $0.48 a share, for the three months ended September 30. Wall Street had expected a loss of just $0.14 a share, according to First Call. In the year-earlier quarter the company had a profit of $48.2 million, or $0.26 a share.
Digital shares were down five at 29-3/8.
It was a different story for Microsoft -- but one familiar in the high-tech sector.

The company reported fiscal first quarter earnings of $0.95 a share, $0.05 above the First Call estimate. But because the stock had a run-up last week when Intel Corp reported a blowout quarter, $0.05 was not good enough for many investors.
Microsoft shares were down two at 132.
Other high techs followed suit, with Intel down 2-1/2 at 105-1/4, Iomega Corp down 1-1/2 at 21-3/4, and Micron Technology Inc down 1-1/8 at 29-1/2.

"The market continues to consolidate last week's gains, and the Nasdaq and the tech sector could continue to see considerable profit-taking," said Scott Bleier, chief investment strategist at Prime Charter Ltd.

"The Dow needs to get back below 6000 as a consolidation-type move," he said. Markets must hammer out the lower and upper boundaries of a new trading range now that the Dow has topped 6000 and the Nasdaq has made a new high, he said.
The Nasdaq will find downside support in the mid-1200 level, Bleier said.
In other earnings-related news, Bristol-Myers Squibb Co was up 1-3/8 at 105-1/2 after the company reported third quarter earnings of $1.50 a share, above the First Call estimate of $1.48.
Eli Lilly & Co reported third quarter operating net per share of $0.76, up from $0.54 a year earlier. The stock was up 1-1/4 at 70.
-- Wall Street Desk 212-859-1737
